description: From Middle English foyle, from Middle French fueille, from Old French fueille (“plant leaf”), from Late Latin folia, the plural of folium, mistaken as a singular feminine.
The literary sense is from the practice of backing a gem with metal foil to make it shine more brilliantly.
Doublet of folio and folium, distantly also with phyllo and phyllon.

entries.meaning: A very thin sheet of metal.
(chiefly uncountable) Thin aluminium/aluminum (or, formerly, tin) used for wrapping food.
examples: wrap the sandwich up in foil

entries.meaning: A thin layer of metal put between a jewel and its setting to make it seem more brilliant.

(authorship, figuratively) In literature, theatre/theater, etc., a character who helps emphasize the traits of the main character and who usually acts as an opponent or antagonist, but can also serve as the sidekick of the protagonist.
(figuratively) Anything that acts by contrast to emphasise the characteristics of something.
examples: Hector has also a foil to set regard

entries.meaning: (fencing) A very thin sword with a blunted (or foiled) tip
examples: Socrates contended with a foil against Demosthenes with a sword.

entries.meaning: A thin, transparent plastic material on which marks are made and projected for the purposes of presentation. See transparency.
A premium trading card with a glossy finish.
examples: I personally would collect all the foils from Base Set before this one, but the market is what the market is.

entries.meaning: (heraldry) A stylized flower or leaf.
(hydrodynamics, nautical) Clipping of hydrofoil.
(aerodynamics, aviation) Clipping of aerofoil/airfoil.

verbs.description: foil (third-person singular simple present foils, present participle foiling, simple past and past participle foiled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cover or wrap with foil.
(nautical) Clipping of hydrofoil.

description: From Middle English foilen (“spoil a scent trail by crossing it”), from Old French fouler (“tread on, trample”), ultimately from Latin fullō (“I trample, I full”).

entries.meaning: Failure when on the point of attainment; defeat; frustration; miscarriage.
examples: Nor e'er was fate so near a foil.

entries.meaning: One of the incorrect answers presented in a multiple-choice test.

verbs.description: foil (third-person singular simple present foils, present participle foiling, simple past and past participle foiled)

entries.meaning: To prevent (something) from being accomplished.
To prevent (someone) from accomplishing something.
examples: I was foiled by my superior

entries.meaning: To blunt; to dull; to spoil.
(obsolete) To tread underfoot; to trample.
examples: King Richard  […]  caused the ensigns of Leopold to be pulled down and foiled underfoot.

entries.meaning: (hunting) The track of an animal.

description: From mnemonic acronym FOIL (“First Outside Inside Last”).

verbs.description: foil (third-person singular simple present foils, present participle foiling, simple past and past participle foiled)

entries.meaning: (mathematics) To expand a product of two or more algebraic expressions, typically binomials.

verbs.description: foil (third-person singular simple present foils, present participle foiling, simple past and past participle foiled)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To defile; to soil.
